attributes.alt: Book cover for Dad's First Day by Mike Wohnoutka. The cover shows a dad sitting behind a child-size classroom desk. He is raising his hand while his son stands next to him smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to introduce ordinal numbers, ask children about their morning routines, and introduce vocabulary
How does Dad feel about the first day of school?
Read for enjoyment, discussing ordinal numbers in context.
Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Tolerate frustration as a step to learning.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Behind the Curtain: Build a Tower
Book or folder to use as a “curtain”
Build a tower out of Connecting Cubes behind a “curtain.”
Guide children to build a matching tower using specific colors first, second, and third.
What do we do at school?
In that book, what happens first? Then what happens?
Pretend you are getting ready for school. What do you do first? Then what do you do next?
Which objects will you use first?
Write about your school day. What do you do first?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
Tell a friend how to stack two blocks. Explain what to do first and then second.

attributes.alt: Book cover for Dad's First Day by Mike Wohnoutka. The cover shows a dad sitting behind a child-size classroom desk. He is raising his hand while his son stands next to him smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to learn about tolerating frustration and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder, as well as describe experiences using ordinal numbers.
Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Challenge children to get into a line in height order without talking.
Guide children to use ordinal numbers to say their place in line.
What do we do at school?
What feelings are in the book?
Pretend that something happened to make your friend frustrated. Act out what you can do to help your friend.
Show three blocks in a line. Which is first? Second? Third?
Tell about how you felt on your first day of school.
Draw about your first day of school.
What letters are in your name? Do you know what sound each letter makes?
Can you use the blocks to build your favorite place in school?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Dad's First Day by Mike Wohnoutka. The cover shows a dad sitting behind a child-size classroom desk. He is raising his hand while his son stands next to him smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review location words, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
How can you tell that Oliver’s dad feels nervous?
Read interactively for a deeper understanding of measurement.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Guide children to place counters on a specific part of an image based on clues that use location words.
What do we do at school?
Are there any location words in your book? How did they help you understand the story?
Why might you get frustrated? Act it out.
Tell a partner where to put counters on the table. Use location words.
How do you feel when you try something new?
Draw a picture of the classroom. Use location words to tell a friend where three things are in the picture.
Can you write the first letter of your name? What sound does it make?
What materials do you see next to the blocks? Is there anything above the blocks?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Our School Rules. The rules show that we share, we clean up, we take turns, we listen, we stay safe, and we are kind.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Our School Rules

attributes.alt: Book cover for Dad's First Day by Mike Wohnoutka. The cover shows a dad sitting behind a child-size classroom desk. He is raising his hand while his son stands next to him smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the school rules and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question,
What do we do at school?
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Review the rules for Simon Says.
Give children directions containing location words.
What do we do at school?
Would you rather listen to a story or act out a story?
Pretend you are following a school rule. What rule you are acting out? Why it is important?
Put five Connecting Cubes in a row. Which one is second in line?
Write about something more exciting you did yesterday.
Make a sign to remind others to follow the school rules better.
Build your favorite place in school. Why is that place your favorite?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Dad's First Day by Mike Wohnoutka. The cover shows a dad sitting behind a child-size classroom desk. He is raising his hand while his son stands next to him smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review time words, engage children with song, and review two important vocabulary words
How can we tell how the people we know are feeling?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Support children as they   independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What do you like most about our school?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What do we do at school?
If you wrote your own book about school, what would you write about?
Pretend you are the teacher in a classroom. Can you tell the children where to put away their materials using location words?
Look at an object in the room. Use location words to help a partner find it.
Write a story about a celebration. What happens first? Second?
Create a party hat for a celebration.
What song do you sing at a birthday celebration? What letter sound do you hear at the beginning of
Which blocks did you create with the most this week? Why?
